_header: Fortune alas alas what have I guilt
_description: ‘Complaint of a Prisoner against Fortune’ — twenty or twenty-one stanzas rhyme royal

BLAdd34360.First Lines:
Allas fortune allas what have I giltIn prisoune thus to lye here
                    desolate…
BLAdd34360.Last Lines:
…Now lady swete I can nomore now seyBut Rewe on me and help me
                    whan I dey
BLAdd34360.Note:
20 stanzas; follows immediately after first three stanzas of
                    Chaucer’s ‘Complaint to his purse…’ (6044) as if part of
                    that poem; ends, ‘Amen’.

BLHar2251.First Lines:
Allas fortune alas what have I giltIn prison thus to lye here
                    desolate…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…Now lady swete I cannomore now seyBut Rewe on me and help me
                    whan I dey Amen
BLHar2251.Note:
Medieval folios 298-300; 20 stanzas; follows immediately after first
                    three stanzas of Chaucer’s ‘Complaint to his purse…’
                        (6044) as if
                    part of that poem.
BLHar2251.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             Originals and Analogues of some of Chaucer’s Canterbury
                Tales.
Chaucer Society
         2nd ser. 7, 10, 15, 20, 22. London: Trübner, 1872-87: App. i-vi.
Hammond,  Eleanor Prescott. 
             “Lament of a Prisoner against Fortune.” 
             Anglia
         32 (1909): 481-90: 484-90.

BLHar7333.First Lines:
FOrtune alas alas what haue I gyltIn prison thus to lye here
                    desolate…
BLHar7333.Last Lines:
…Now lady swete I can nomore now sayBut rew on me and helpe me
                    when I dey
BLHar7333.Attributed Title:
Here next folowith a litell Tretys by wey of complaint Agenis ffortune (f.
                        30va); Explicit le compleint Agein ffortune (f.
                    31ra)
BLHar7333.Editions:
Hammond,  Eleanor Prescott. 
             “Lament of a Prisoner against Fortune.” 
             Anglia
         32 (1909): 481-90: 484-90.
